definition:
A number in the sequence created from the recurrence relation
$$P_n = 2P_{n - 1} + P_{n - 2},$$ with $$P_0 = 0$$ and $$P_1 = 1.$$ The
first few Pell numbers are 0, 1, 2, 5, 12, 29, 70, 169, 408, 985, listed
in A000129 of Sloane’s OEIS.

A Pell number for any given index can also be calculated from earlier
Pell numbers with $$P_{a + b} = P_aP_{b + 1} + P_{a - 1}P_b.$$

The formula
$${ {-{(1 - \sqrt 2)}^n + {(1 + \sqrt 2)}^n} \over {2\sqrt 2}}$$ works
too. From this particular formula it can be deduced that the sequence of
Pell numbers can be used in a continued fraction of the square root of 2
as well as the silver ratio.

Yet another way to calculate Pell numbers is by squaring the terms of
Pascal’s triangle and adding up the antidiagonals. Arranging the Markov
numbers in a binary graph tree and reading the numbers on 2’s branch
gives the Pell numbers with odd indices.

Only Pell numbers with prime indexes can also be prime. This fact is
used in some tests for pseudoprimality.
